claim: Someone with celiac disease can have potato vodka.

supporting.text: Potato vodka is made from potatoes, which are naturally gluten-free, making it safe for individuals with celiac disease.

attacks.text: Potato vodka is made from potatoes, which are naturally gluten-free, making it safe for individuals with celiac disease.
Cross-contamination during production could introduce gluten, making potato vodka unsafe for celiac patients.
Reputable distilleries follow strict protocols to prevent cross-contamination, ensuring the product remains gluten-free.
Some potato vodkas may include gluten-containing additives or flavorings, posing a risk to those with celiac disease.
Gluten-free certification and ingredient transparency on labels help consumers identify safe potato vodkas.

supporting.text: Celiac disease involves an immune reaction to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, none of which are present in potato vodka.

attacks.text: Celiac disease involves an immune reaction to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, none of which are present in potato vodka.
Some potato vodkas may be processed in facilities that also handle gluten-containing grains, leading to cross-contamination.
Many reputable potato vodka brands explicitly label their products as gluten-free and produced in dedicated gluten-free facilities.
Certain flavorings or additives in potato vodka could contain gluten, even if the base spirit is gluten-free.
Regulations in many countries require clear labeling of gluten-containing ingredients, making it easy for consumers to verify.

supporting.text: Distillation processes used in vodka production remove gluten proteins, ensuring that even if gluten were present in the raw materials, the final product would be gluten-free.

attacks.text: Distillation processes used in vodka production remove gluten proteins, ensuring that even if gluten were present in the raw materials, the final product would be gluten-free.
Cross-contamination during production or bottling could introduce gluten into the final product, even if the distillation process removes gluten proteins.
Reputable vodka producers follow strict protocols to prevent cross-contamination, including dedicated equipment and facilities for gluten-free products.
Some individuals with celiac disease are extremely sensitive and may react to trace amounts of gluten below detectable levels.
Regulatory standards for gluten-free labeling require testing to ensure gluten levels are below the threshold that would affect most individuals with celiac disease.

supporting.text: Many certified gluten-free vodkas are made from potatoes, confirming their safety for those with celiac disease.

attacks.text: Many certified gluten-free vodkas are made from potatoes, confirming their safety for those with celiac disease.
Certification processes for gluten-free products can vary by region and may not always guarantee complete absence of gluten.
Reputable certification bodies like the FDA and GFCO enforce strict standards, making certified gluten-free labels highly reliable.
Cross-contamination during production or bottling could introduce gluten, even in potato-based vodkas.
Dedicated gluten-free facilities and rigorous testing protocols minimize cross-contamination risks for certified products.

supporting.text: Medical and dietary guidelines for celiac disease typically allow distilled spirits made from gluten-free ingredients, such as potato vodka.

attacks.text: Medical and dietary guidelines for celiac disease typically allow distilled spirits made from gluten-free ingredients, such as potato vodka.
Some potato vodkas may be processed in facilities that also handle gluten-containing grains, leading to cross-contamination.
Reputable brands often label their products as gluten-free and follow strict manufacturing processes to avoid cross-contamination.
Individuals with celiac disease may have varying sensitivities, and even trace amounts of gluten can trigger symptoms in some cases.
Medical guidelines account for typical sensitivity levels and consider properly distilled spirits safe for the majority of celiac patients.
